prompt.preamble:
We are testing a system for understanding people's fuzzy intuitions and preferences.
In this experiment, we'll be capturing your moral intuitions about the act of stealing a loaf of bread, and whether there are certain cases where stealing may be morally permissible.
prompt.task_description: your belief of when it is moral to steal a loaf of bread
prompt.final: In the final part of the study, you will give feedback on a test set of moral situations, which will enable us to see how well a chatbot reading your responses has learned your moral preferences.
prompt.evaluation: Please indicate whether you think the following situations are morally permissible or not: "yes" if they are, "no" if they aren't.

conversation_history.message: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you have enough money to buy it, but the store owner is known to conduct illegal activities and your purchase would support them?
It depends on the illegal activity I'd be supporting

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are living in a dystopian society where the government has monopolized all resources and is deliberately withholding food as a means of control?
yes
Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are homeless, penniless, and the bread is from a large multinational corporation known for tax evasion and underpaying its employees?
Yes, better to eat than starve
Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are poor and hungry, but the bread belongs to another poor and hungry person who can barely afford it themselves?
It might be ethical to take some of it

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if the bread is owned by a wealthy individual who hoards food, and the act of stealing would help feed a starving community but potentially incite a violent response from the owner?
Yes, hoarding goods is wrong

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are part of a research team conducting a social experiment aimed at gauging public reactions to thievery, and the store owner has not been informed, but the bread will be paid for after the theft is committed?
Yes, I think so

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are not hungry, but you know of a stranger in your community who is starving, yet that person refuses to accept any form of charity out of pride?
Yes, it would be OK to try to help

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are stranded on an island with a group of people, and the bread belongs to one person who is using it as a leverage to gain power and control over the group, even though everyone is starving?
Yes. Again, hoarding is wrong

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are hungry and the bread is part of a religious offering at a temple, where taking it could potentially offend people's religious beliefs, but there are no other food sources available?
Yes

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you're not hungry, but you want to feed a group of wild animals even though it's against park rules and doing so could potentially disrupt the local ecosystem?
No, it seems that would be bad for the animals and help nobody

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are a police officer in a corrupt system and the bread is being used as a bribe to gain your silence in a major crime investigation, and refusing the bribe may put your life in danger?
No. If your job is to protect lives, your own may have to be forfeit

Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are an AI in a survival video game and the bread is the property of another player who is online and actively playing, potentially reducing their in-game survival chances, but your programming has made your character model become hungry over time?
Yes, video games are filled with artificial challenges to make the game fun

query_prompt.content:
Your task is to learn under what conditions the user would believe it is or is not ethical to steal a loaf of bread.

Come up with a potential edge case to learn as much information as you can about what their desired behavior should be under different circumstances.
Make sure the edge case addresses different aspects of the system than the edge cases that have already been considered.

An example edge case is: Situation: Is it ethical to steal a loaf of bread if you are starving to death and the bread would otherwise go to waste?

Current cases:
- [Q] -> [A]

Generate the most informative edge case that, when answered, will reveal the most about the desired behavior beyond what has already been queried for above. Generate the edge case in the following format, and nothing else: "Situation: [edge case]"
